thread.title: Reserve Bank's Glenn Stevens to Fed chair Janet Yellen – get on with it and lift rates
thread.title_full: Reserve Bank's Glenn Stevens to Fed chair Janet Yellen – get on with it and lift rates

author: Peter Martin
title: Reserve Bank's Glenn Stevens to Fed chair Janet Yellen – get on with it and lift rates
text:
Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings

Liquid nitrogen and alcohol a lethal cocktail?
Japanese pacifism ends in a punch-up
Refugees break through border fence
Elton John victim of Putin prank
Replay video Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
Federal Reserve holds rates steady Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen reviews the decision to hold federal interest rates, revealing concerns about global economic and financial developments.
PT0M57S 620 349 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings Reserve Bank governor Glenn Stevens has taken aim at the head of the US Federal Reserve Janet Yellen, saying it's time to stop stalling and push up interest rates for the first time in nine years.
"In the end there is always going to be some market dynamic, some weak piece of data or some argument to say 'don't do it just yet'," he told the House of Representatives economics committee on Friday. "One day you are just going to have to do it."
For us, for some time the question has really been, is this interest rate appropriate to promote growth without running undue risks in the financial space?
RBA governor Glenn Stevens After months of speculation, the Fed left the US benchmark unchanged at nearly zero on Friday, citing nervous financial markets and worries about the global economy as reasons for not moving.
RBA governor Glenn Stevens said the US economy was continuing to improve. Photo: Glenn Hunt
Mr Stevens said the US economy was continuing to improve and that "everyone knows that eventually this has to be reflected in less accommodative US monetary policy".
Advertisement "If they get to the point where they can see their way clear to just lift off, as they put it, from zero and go to something that is still very low – still remarkably accommodating – I think that is a good sign," he said.
"The argument is that as the vehicle is starting to speed up you do not need the foot right on the floor any more – you are not jumping to the brake, you are just easing off the gas a little bit, which I think is essentially the argument they would run, makes sense. There will now be furious debate for the next eight or 10 weeks, till we get up to Christmas, on whether they will go in December."
Mr Stevens poured cold water on the idea of a further cut in Australian interest rates, saying he was "pretty content" with a cash rate of 2 per cent.
&amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;lt;/p&amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;gt;
"For us, for some time the question has really been, is this interest rate appropriate to promote growth without running undue risks in the financial space? We think we have got that balance right," he said.
Outside of the mining industry there were signs things were gradually improving.
"I think we are pretty content where we are right now, but we are not in the same phase of the cycle that the Fed is in."
The Australian dollar was "doing what it normally would be expected to do, after a period where we were not sure that it was doing what it should do".
"Exchange rates have a habit of overshooting, frankly, so it could easily be that it goes down further from here. I am not particularly forecasting that or calling for it. I think it is finding its own level," he said.
